verses.verse: So at that time Pilate took Jesus and whipped Him.
And the soldiers who wove an award wreath from thorns placed it on His head and put a purple robe around Him.
And they were saying, "Welcome, the King of the Jewish people," and they were giving Him slaps.
So Pilate came outside again and says to them, "Look, I lead Him outside to you so that you might know that in Him I don't find even one accusation."
So Jesus came outside wearing the thorny award wreath and the purple robe. And he says to them, "Look, the Person."

So when the head priests and the rowers saw Him, they made a yell, saying, "Nail Him to a cross. Nail Him to a cross." Pilate says to them, "You must take Him and nail Him to a cross. You see, I don't find in Him an accusation."
The Jewish people responded to him, "We have a law, and according to our law He ought to die because He made Himself a son of God."
So when Pilate heard this saying, he was more afraid.
And he went into the Roman fort again. And he says to Jesus, "Where are You from?" But Jesus did not give him a response.
So Pilate says to Him, "Are You not speaking to me? Don't You realize that I have authority to nail You to a cross and I have authority to dismiss You?"
Jesus answered, "You don't have even one bit of authority against Me unless it has been given to you from above. Because of this, the one who turned Me over to you has a bigger sin."

From this time on, Pilate was looking to dismiss Him, but the Jewish people were yelling, saying, "If you dismiss this Man, you are not a friend of Caesar. Everyone making himself a king is expressing opposition to Caesar."
So when Pilate heard this saying, he led Jesus outside and was seated on the judicial bench in a place called "Stone Mosaic" ("Gabbatha" in Hebrew).
It was a preparation day of the Passover, but an hour as if it were the sixth (noon). And he says to the Jewish people, "Look, your King."

But the people made a yell, "Take Him away. Take Him away. Nail Him to a cross." Pilate said to them, "Will I nail your King to a cross?" The head priests answered, "We do not have a king except Caesar."
So at that time, he turned Him over to them so that He might be nailed to a cross. They took Jesus along and led Him away.
And hauling His cross, He went out to the place called Place of a Skull, that in Hebrew is called Golgotha,
where they nailed Him to a cross and two others with Him, on this side and on this side, but Jesus in the middle.
Pilate also wrote a caption and placed it on the cross. It had been written, "Jesus, the Nazarene, the King of the Jewish people."
So this caption many of the Jewish people read because the place was near the city where Jesus was nailed to a cross and it had been written in Hebrew, in Latin, in Greek.
So the head priests of the Jewish people were saying to Pilate, "Don't write, 'The King of the Jewish people,' but 'That Man said I am a king of the Jewish people'."
Pilate answered, "What I have written, I have written."

So the soldiers, when they nailed Jesus to a cross, took His clothes and made four parts, a part for each soldier, and the long undershirt. But the long unsewed undershirt was woven from the top through all of it.

So they said to each other, "We should not split it up, but we should throw dice concerning it, whose it will be." This happened so that the Old Testament writing (in Psalm 22:18) might be accomplished that says, "They thoroughly divided my clothes for themselves and threw dice on my clothing." So the soldiers certainly did these things.
His mother, the sister of His mother, Mary (the wife of Clopas), and Mary (the Magdalene) had stood beside the cross of Jesus.
So when Jesus saw His mother and the student whom He kept loving standing nearby, He says to His mother, "Ma'am, look, your son."
After that He says to the student, "Look, your mother." And from that hour, the student took her to his own places.
After this, Jesus realizing that He had already finished everything, so that the Old Testament writing (in Psalm 69:21) might be completed, He says, "I am thirsty."
So a container was lying there full of sour wine. After they filled a sponge with sour wine and put it around a hyssop stick, they offered it to His mouth.
So when Jesus took the sour wine, He said, "It has been finished." And when He tilted His head, He gave up the spirit.

So the Jewish people, since it was a preparation day, so that the bodies wouldn't stay on the cross during the Sabbath (you see, the day of that Sabbath was huge), they asked Pilate that their legs would be broken and they would be taken away
So the soldiers went and certainly broke the legs of the first man and of the other man, the man who was nailed to a cross together with Him.
But when they came up to Jesus, as they saw that He had already died, they didn't break His legs.
But one of the soldiers stabbed His side with a spear, and right away blood and water came out.
And the person who has seen it has told what he witnessed, and his witness account is true. And that person realizes that he is saying truthful things, so that you might trust.
You see, these things happened so that the Old Testament writing (in Exodus 12:46, Numbers 9:12, and Psalm 34:20) might be accomplished. "A bone of His will not be crushed."
And again a different Old Testament writing says, (in Zechariah 12:10) "They will look to whom they pierced."

After these things, Joseph (the one out of Arimathaea, who was a student of Jesus, but had been hid because of his fear of the Jewish people) asked Pilate that he might take the body of Jesus, and Pilate gave permission. So he went and took the body of Jesus.
Nicodemus (the one who came to Jesus at night the first time) also came, bringing a mixture of myrrh (expensive perfume) and aloe, as if it were a hundred pounds.
So they took the body of Jesus and tied it up in linen strips with the fragrant spices, just as the custom is for the Jewish people to be preparing a corpse for burial.
In the place where He was nailed to a cross, there was a garden, and in the garden a new burial vault in which no one was placed yet.
So they put Jesus there because of the preparation day of the Jewish people, because the burial vault was near.
